Talked to Adam, who said that this can be recreated by setting a breakpoint in the debugger.  When debugger reaches breakpoint, get exception in JSDebugThread.onExecute().

I tried this on Win32, and could not recreate.  But I just noticed that the "OS" field is set to Linux, so I'll test on Linux tomorrow.

Here's the stack trace on the C++ side of things:

#0  nsWindow::Enable (this=0x9f971ab0, aState=0) at /home/javier/builds/xulrunner18/mozilla/widget/src/gtk2/nsWindow.cpp:649
#1  0xa1835a16 in nsWebBrowser::SetEnabled (this=0x9f989a70, aEnabled=0) at /home/javier/builds/xulrunner18/mozilla/embedding/browser/webBrowser/nsWebBrowser.cpp:1441
#2  0xa0f108bd in XPTC_InvokeByIndex () at nsIInterfaceRequestorUtils.h:60
#3  0xa0f9351c in Java_org_mozilla_xpcom_internal_XPCOMJavaProxy_callXPCOMMethod (env=0x805bfe8, that=0xbff5f404, aJavaProxy=0xbff5f414, aMethodName=0xbff5f410, aParams=0xbff5f40c) at /home/javier/builds/xulrunner18/mozilla/extensions/java/xpcom/src/../nsJavaWrapper.cpp:1517

The top method looks like this:
 646 NS_IMETHODIMP
 647 nsWindow::Enable(PRBool aState)
 648 {
 649     return NS_ERROR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
 650 }

So this method is only useful on Win32.  Maybe wrap it with a try/catch block, and re-throw any XPCOMException that doesn't have an errorcode == NS_ERROR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED?
